citation.article-title: Reduction of elemental sulfur by moderately thermophilic organotrophic bacteria and the description of Thermoanaerobacter sulfurophilus sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Thermoanaerobacter sulfurophilus sp. nov.
Thermoanaerobacter sulfurophilus sp. nov. (sul.fu.ro.phi'lus. L. masc. adj., sulfurophilus, of L. n. sulfur—sulfur and GK. masc. adj. philos—liking: sulfurophilus—liking elemental sulfur)
Cells are curved rods, 3–7 × 0.5 μm, sometimes in chains, gram-positive, motile due to peritrichous flagellation.
Grows at 44–75°C, with an optimum at 55–60°C, and in a pH range of 4.5–8.0, with an optimum at 6.9– 7.2.
Growth substrates are glucose, fructose, lactose, rhamnose, arabinose, xylose, sorbitol, inositol, mannitol, sucrose, cellobiose, lactose, maltose, starch, pectin, pyruvate, and lactate.
No growth on cellulose, succinate, citrate, formate, acetate, propionate, butyrate, methanol, ethanol, or H2.
The major metabolic products are H2, CO2, and acetate; minor amounts of ethanol are produced along with trace amounts of lactate.
Elemental sulfur and thiosulfate stimulate growth and are reduced to hydrogen sulfide.
Sulfate, sulfite, and nitrate are not reduced and have no effect on growth.
G+C content of DNA is 30.3 ± 0.5 mol %.
Source of isolation: cyanobacterial mat in a sulfiderich hot pond, the Uzon caldera, Kamchatka.
